document.masterDocTitle: A revision of the subfamily Araeopteroninae Fibiger, 2005 in the Russian Far East and neighbouring countries with a description of four new species (Lepidoptera, Noctuidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A revision of the subfamily Araeopteroninae Fibiger, 2005 in the Russian Far East and neighbouring countries with a description of four new species (Lepidoptera, Noctuidae)

bibRefCitation.author: Inoue
bibRefCitation.refString: Inoue, H. (1958) Three new species of the genus Araeopteron (Lepidoptera, Noctuidae) from Japan. Tinea, 4 (1), 229 - 233.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Araeopteron amoena
Inoue, 1958
,
Tinea
4 : 230 , Pl. 32 , fig. 2 (imago), fig. 4 (male genitalia), fig. 6 (wing venation). TL: Japan : Kanagawa Pref., Chigasaki [ BMNH , London].

CHINA :
11 males
and females, Prov. Chekiang, West Tien-mu-shan
27 .iv– 29 .ix. 1932
(H. Höne);
1 male
, Prov. Hunnan, Hoengshan
27 .iv. 1933
(H. Höne);
17 males
and females, China , Prov. Henan, Tongbai 300 m ,
11–13 .ix. 2000
(O. Karsholt & Nankai Univ. Tianjin ). Colls. ZFMK , ZMUC , and M. Fibiger.

JAPAN :

, Honshu, Nara Pref., Kozjidake 1200 m ,
2 .viii. 1971
(L.R.W. Kobes). Coll. ZSM .

Diagnosis. Adult easily distinguishable from other East Asiatic species by the dark-grey colour of the forewing and broad reddish-brown basal area on the hindwing. The male genitalia differ from other species by having large spine-like extensions of the ampulla and armature of the vesica, with a patch of 10–15 small, thin spines. Females differ by the large, plate-like signum, with long, mostly anteriorly directed spines in the posterior part of the corpus bursae.

Distribution. Russian Far East, Primorye terr. (Fig. 34 ), south of Khabarovsk terr.; south Sakhalin; and south Kuriles, Kunashir I.; South Korea ; Japan (Hokkaido, Honshu, Shikoku, Kyushu, Tsushima I., Yakushima I., Okinawa I. and Honto I.); China (Prov. Chekiang, Hunnan and Henan). In the Far East most common and widely distributed species. First reported for the continental Asia from Russia , Khabarovsk and Primorye territories and Sakhalin by
Viidalepp & Remm ( 1982 )
; reported for South Kuriles (Kunashir I) by
Dubatolov et al. ( 1995 )
.
